Package generation

Class MazeBuilderBoruvka

java.lang.Object
generation.MazeBuilder
generation.MazeBuilderBoruvka
All Implemented Interfaces:
Runnable
public class MazeBuilderBoruvka extends generation.MazeBuilder implements Runnable
Boruvka's Algorithm: Expanding the MST till all cells are connected. for each round, find a minimum cost path for each cell, then connect the cells through the minimum costs. While one single tree is not formed, iterate the process.
Author:
Min Kim

  • Constructor Details

    • MazeBuilderBoruvka

      public MazeBuilderBoruvka()
      The logger is used to track execution and report issues.

  • Method Details

    • generatePathways

      public void generatePathways()
      This method generates pathways into the maze by using Boruvka's algorithm. The cells are the nodes of the graph and the spanning tree. An edge represents that one can move from one cell to an adjacent cell. So an edge implies that its nodes are adjacent cells in the maze and that there is no wallboard separating these cells in the maze.

    • getEdgeWeight

      public int getEdgeWeight(int x, int y, generation.CardinalDirection cd)
      Get a value of a wallboard of a cell. If a value is already assigned to a wallboard, then it simply returns the original value. If a value is not assigned yet, pick a random value from 1 to 10 and return it.
      Parameters:
      x - the width-value of a cell
      y - the height-value of a cell
      cd - the direction of a wallboard of a cell. (ex. North, East, West, South)
      Returns:
      an integer that is a value of a wallboard.

    • initialization

      public void initialization(int[][][] data)
      Set up for Boruvka's algorithm. Using 3-dimensional array, we store values for width, height, and direction of each cell. x side represents width, y side represents height, and z side represents either index value or direction value. z[0] represents an index value for each cell, and z[1~4] represent direction value. starting from top-left cell, assign an index value starting from 0, incrementing each time. Also, for each cell, assign a value for each wallboard. For wallboard to the east and south side, call getEdgeWeight to get a value randomly. For wallboard to the north and west side, since it is a duplicate wall with a cell above and next, simply copy the value that is already assigned.
      Parameters:
      data - 3-dimensional array data, where each cell in an array will take width, height, direction value of a cell in maze.

    • findMinPlace

      public int[] findMinPlace(Set<Integer> a)
      By finding a minimum path using the findMin method(below), we are ready to find the actual wallboard that we are going to remove and connect to the next cell. With the minimum value, iterate all the wallboards of the cells in the sets to find the list of wallboards that contain the minimum value. If there is more than one, we randomly select a wallboard to remove.
      Parameters:
      a - a set of integers which represents the set of already connected cells.
      Returns:
      an array of integers that represent the coordinate of a cell and the direction of a wallboard, which will be removed.

    • findMin

      public int findMin(Set<Integer> a)
      For each trees(sets), we have to find a minimum path to connect to the next cells. This method helps finding a minimum value of a wallboard of the cell in the set, which has not been removed yet.
      Parameters:
      a - a set of integers which represents the set of already connected cells.
      Returns:
      an integer that represents the smallest value of a wallboard that has not been removed.

    • indxTodim

      public int[] indxTodim(int a)
      input an index value of a cell to know where the cell is located at.
      Parameters:
      a - an index value of a cell
      Returns:
      an array containing two values: x coordinate and y coordinate of a cell.

    • dimToindx

      public int dimToindx(int[] a)
      input a coordinate of a cell to find an index value of the cell.
      Parameters:
      a - an array containing two values: x coordinate and y coordinate of a cell.
      Returns:
      an index value of a cell

    • dirToInt

      public int dirToInt(generation.CardinalDirection cd)
      Switch the direction to the corresponding integer.
      Parameters:
      cd - a direction of the wallboard of the cell.
      Returns:
      an integer which represents a direction.

    • intToDir

      public generation.CardinalDirection intToDir(int drInt)
      Switch the integer that represents a direction to a direction itself.
      Parameters:
      drInt - an integer which represents a direction.
      Returns:
      a direction of the wallboard of the cell.

    • updateSet

      public void updateSet(int[] a, Set<Integer> b)
      When the wallboard is removed, we have to add the cell that is newly connected by the absence of the wallboard. using the index value of a cell gained from the coordinate and the direction, we can determine which new cell to be connected based on which side of the wallboard is removed.
      Parameters:
      a - an array of an integer, which represents the coordinate of a cell and the direction of wallboard of a cell.
      b - a set of Integers, which represent a tree.

    • updateList

      public void updateList(ArrayList<Set<Integer>> a)
      After each time sets are newly updated, we also have to update the list of sets. If sets have duplicate values, meaning that they contain the same cell, we have to merge them, since they are connected already. After moving all the values of one set to another, delete the set, so that we now have one big set.
      Parameters:
      a - an Arraylist of sets of integers, which represent the list of trees that are making the maze.

    • isDuplicate

      public boolean isDuplicate(Set<Integer> a, Set<Integer> b)
      By iterating through two sets, we can find whether there is a duplicate value in the set, meaning that two sets are supposed to be connected, since they have the same cell.
      Parameters:
      a - two sets of Integers, which represent two trees.
      b - two sets of Integers, which represent two trees.
      Returns:
      whether two sets have duplicate values or not.
